Key Arguments: Current COVID-19 vaccine trials are not designed to detect a reduction in severe outcomes such as hospital admissions or deaths.
The trials focus on mild symptomatic COVID-19 as the primary endpoint, which may not provide a complete picture of vaccine efficacy.
There is a lack of data on whether the vaccines can prevent virus transmission.
The trials may not adequately represent vulnerable populations, such as the elderly and minorities, which could affect the generalizability of the results.
There is concern about the potential for serious adverse events from vaccines developed under pressure.
Notable Quotes: None of the trials currently under way are designed to detect a reduction in any serious outcome such as hospital admissions, use of intensive care, or deaths.
Our trial will not demonstrate prevention of transmission because in order to do that you have to swab people twice a week for very long periods, and that becomes operationally untenable.

If we don’t have adequate data in the greater than 65 year old group, then the greater than 65 year old person shouldn’t get this vaccine, which would be a shame because they’re the ones who are most likely to die from this infection.
